Yes, the post-Abbas era has begun. But the bad news is the legacy he leaves behind after twenty-one years in power—a legacy defined by three structural disasters.
First, a public debt exceeding $16 billion, entirely owed to domestic Palestinian sources: local banks, suppliers, pension funds, and unpaid salaries. This debt cannot be ignored or postponed. Even if 3 percent of Palestinian GDP were allocated annually to repayment, it would take decades to settle—condemning generations to inherited insolvency.
Second, roughly 400 laws enacted by presidential decree in the absence of a functioning parliament. Reviewing, correcting, repealing, or replacing this distorted legislative framework will require years of intensive parliamentary work—likely one to two full legislative terms devoted almost entirely to undoing past damage rather than legislating for the future.
Third, the sale of thousands of dunams of state land in the West Bank through so-called “allocation decisions,” representing one of the largest corruption schemes carried out beyond public scrutiny—a structural crime whose consequences are extraordinarily difficult to reverse.

label: Sawsan Sinijlawi
text:
PA reform: facts vs. slogans

Good news: we are entering a post-Abbas era.
Bad news: the institutional burdens left behind will take generations to fix.

Since the Palestinian parliament stopped functioning in 2007, Abbas shifted to rule-by-decree.
≈450+ presidential decrees replaced legislation.
Revising, amending, or repealing this body of decrees will require 8–10 years of intensive parliamentary work.
That means three consecutive elected Palestinian Legislative Councils, assuming regular elections every four years, would be consumed largely by undoing this legacy.

At the same time, the PA accumulated ~$16B in debt and arrears.
Under current economic conditions, even a future democratic government would need 5–6 decades to repay this without debt restructuring and sustained external support.
In other words: four Palestinian generations would continue paying the price.

This is not about personalities.
It is about institutions, accountability, and the cost of governing without a functioning parliament.

There is only one real reform:
National legislative and presidential elections.
Anything else is cosmetic — slogans without substance.

Gaza Deserves Life

This is not a position against anyone. It is a position for humanity. This child dancing at a wedding in Gaza reminds us of a simple truth too often lost in conflict:
children are not a threat, and they are not born as enemies.
Every child in Gaza and in Tel Aviv alike has the same right to safety, to joy, and to a future not governed by rockets or fear.

Real security is not built by force alone. It is built by creating a reality where children do not need hatred to feel protected.
Policies that suffocate the daily life of an entire society may create temporary calm, but they do not produce sustainable peace.

The dance in this video is not a denial of pain. It is an expression of resilience and attachment to life. And that is precisely what must be protected if we are serious about a different future.

Recognizing the right of Gaza’s children to live does not undermine Israel’s security. It strengthens the understanding that security and peace are not opposites, but partners.
A peace that ignores the humanity of the other will not endure.
A peace that begins with children may still be possible.
Gaza deserves life just as every  Israeli and Palestinian child in this land does.

Why Israeli Skepticism Is Understandable—And Why Engagement in the Board of Peace Is Essential

After several interviews with Israeli media following the launch of the @BoardOfPeace Board of Peace in Davos, I encountered deep skepticism.  Skepticism is not cynicism; it is experience.

But the initiative launched in Davos this year—the Board of Peace chaired by @realDonaldTrump President Donald J. Trump—is not another declarative peace process. It is a governing mechanism built around authority, leverage, and measurable outcomes. That difference matters.

In Davos, two visions of global order appeared side by side. One was familiar: speeches lamenting the collapse of the so-called rules-based international system. Leaders spoke openly of a “pleasant fiction” coming to an end. For many in the Middle East, this was not a revelation. It was a delayed admission. The rules existed—but they were applied selectively, enforced unevenly, and often detached from accountability.

The Board of Peace did not emerge to mourn this system or replace it rhetorically. It emerged from a different governing philosophy—one skeptical of process for its own sake and focused instead on delivery. Clear authority. Defined responsibility. Measurable goals. Accountability.

When @jaredkushner Jared Kushner presented Gaza’s future in Davos, he did not offer slogans or promises. He presented institutional design, budgets, timelines, and governance structures. For Palestinians and Israelis alike, this marked a departure from decades of diplomatic theater. It was not another promise to “support peace.” It was an attempt to build it.

For Palestinians, this matters because Gaza is not an abstraction. It is two million people living among ruins, where delay fuels extremism and institutional collapse empowers militias. Action is not ideological; it is moral.

For Israelis, the stakes are no less concrete. A reconstructed Gaza governed by accountable institutions is not a concession—it is a security interest. Stability achieved through functioning governance, economic dignity, and regional responsibility is more sustainable than deterrence achieved through force alone.

Israeli skepticism toward international mechanisms is justified. But disengagement would be a mistake. This process cannot succeed without Israeli involvement, scrutiny, and conditional support. Supporting the framework does not mean suspending doubt—it means shaping outcomes.

Critics argue that action without universal consensus risks abuse of power. That concern is legitimate. But consensus without enforcement has already failed. The real question is not whether power will exist in peacebuilding, but whether it will be exercised transparently, responsibly, and with measurable accountability.

If this model succeeds, it will not be because it sounded better. It will be because it delivered schools instead of statements, salaries instead of sympathy, and security instead of slogans.

For Israel, this is not about faith in diplomacy. It is about advancing a strategic interest: replacing perpetual instability on its southern border with accountable governance. For the region, it is a test of whether reconstruction and cooperation can finally replace endless war management.

Skepticism is healthy. Engagement is essential. The difference between the two will shape what comes next.

The discussion about Gaza’s future would benefit from a more careful listening to Palestinian voices themselves.
Yes, Palestinians overwhelmingly support national unity. But they seek productive unity—one that delivers accountable governance, dignity, and effective institutions, not the recycling of failed models.
Reattaching Gaza to the current Palestinian Authority leadership in Ramallah, without reform or renewal, risks deepening Gaza’s suffering rather than alleviating it. A leadership that has accumulated approximately $16 billion in public debt, largely amid widespread allegations of corruption and mismanagement, is unlikely to inspire confidence in its ability to oversee the most complex reconstruction effort in Palestinian history with transparency and efficiency.
A governing system that struggles to manage the Allenby/King Hussein Bridge in a manner that respects citizens cannot credibly be expected to administer the far more sensitive Rafah Crossing. A health system that fails to provide adequate care in the West Bank cannot realistically rebuild Gaza’s devastated medical sector. And a political elite increasingly disconnected from daily Palestinian realities cannot fully grasp what it means to live for months in displacement camps and temporary shelters.
Some Arab and European diplomats continue to insist on restoring the status quo in Gaza out of concern for “unity.” In many cases, this position reflects institutional inertia and political caution, rather than a deep understanding of Palestinian public sentiment or the scale of Gaza’s post-war challenges.
Palestinians want unity—but unity achieved through national elections, legitimate representation, and credible reform. Until such elections are possible, governance models must reflect present realities. Gaza today is not a peripheral issue; it has become the center of Palestinian political gravity. This shift may be uncomfortable for some policymakers, but ignoring it will only delay stability and reconstruction.
Listening to Palestinians—rather than deciding on their behalf—remains the most responsible path forward.

Peace will not begin with slogans or structures alone — it will begin when Palestinians and Israelis reconnect at that human level.

The newly formed Technocratic Government of Gaza officially received its letters of appointment, signed by the Board of Peace, with a formal public announcement expected in the coming hours. This cabinet is composed of independent Gazan professionals who belong neither to the Palestinian Authority nor to Hamas. These are individuals rooted in Gaza’s society, economy, and institutions—many of whom lived through the war, endured its consequences, and remained engaged with their communities throughout the most difficult months.
Leadership and Key Figures
The government will be headed by Dr. Ali Shaath, a respected academic and public policy figure known for his technocratic approach, independence, and long-standing engagement with governance, development, and institutional reform.

@ayed621 Eng. Ayed Abu Ramadan – a leading economic and private-sector figure in Gaza, widely recognized for his role in sustaining commercial life under blockade and conflict, and for advocating practical economic recovery mechanisms grounded in local capacity.

Hana Tarzi – a prominent civil-society voice, representing community engagement, humanitarian coordination, and the lived experience of Gaza’s social fabric during the war and its aftermath.
Together, these figures represent a new governing ethos: professional, civilian, locally anchored, and future-oriented.
What This Means for Gaza
This development is not merely a change of names—it is a structural shift.
Gaza is entering a phase that prioritizes:
Reconstruction over militarization
Institutions over factions
Service delivery over slogans
Economic revival over dependency
Dignity, accountability, and normal life over permanent emergency
The technocratic government is expected to focus on rebuilding critical infrastructure, restoring public services, stabilizing the economy, coordinating humanitarian and development efforts, and preparing Gaza for long-term governance reform and regional integration.
Beyond Gaza
This moment matters not only for Gaza’s residents or for Palestinians as a whole.
A stable, functional Gaza governed by professionals rather than armed factions is a cornerstone for regional stability, Israeli-Palestinian de-escalation, and credible international engagement. It opens the door for reconstruction funding to be tied to transparency and performance, and for Gaza to re-enter regional economic frameworks rather than remain isolated and volatile.
This is not the end of Gaza’s struggle—but it may well be the beginning of its recovery.
For the first time in many years, Gaza is being offered something it has been denied for too long:
a chance to be governed by its people, for its people, with the future in mind.

text:
If EU diplomats are to be discredited whenever hostile actors attempt to flatter them internally, then no serious engagement in conflict zones will remain possible. Diplomacy does not operate in moral laboratories. It operates in fractured realities, among actors who seek constantly to instrumentalize language, presence, and perception. To judge diplomats by how they are privately described by adversarial groups is to adopt the logic of propaganda, not policy.
The consequence of such a standard would not be stronger European principles, but weaker European influence. Access would diminish. Channels would close. The EU would increasingly outsource its presence to intermediaries or withdraw altogether—ceding ground not only to regional powers, but to precisely the radical actors it claims to oppose. The vacuum created by disengagement is never neutral; it is always filled by others.
What this article should therefore prompt is not a campaign of insinuation, retroactive moral scoring, or symbolic outrage, but a sober reaffirmation of how diplomacy actually works—and why it matters. Diplomats are not rewarded for being liked, nor disqualified for being quoted. Their mandate is to represent policy faithfully while navigating environments where clarity, restraint, and human engagement are essential tools—not liabilities.
In Gaza, this balance is uniquely difficult. Any envoy operating there must speak to suffering without legitimizing armed groups; must engage local realities without conferring political recognition; must defend universal principles while refusing ideological alignment. This is not moral ambiguity. It is professional discipline.
Sven Kühn von Burgsdorff operated within this narrow and demanding space. He defended EU principles, articulated internationally recognized rights, and preserved access in one of the most constrained diplomatic theaters in the world. This required maintaining a distinction that is central to European diplomacy: engagement without legitimization, empathy without endorsement, access without compromise.
Undermining that distinction does not strengthen Europe’s moral standing. It erodes it. A Europe that confuses diplomacy with advocacy, or engagement with complicity, will find itself morally louder but strategically absent—present in declarations, absent where influence is actually exercised.
In a region defined by polarization and absolutism, Europe’s credibility has long rested on its capacity to hold complexity without surrendering principle. That capacity should be defended, not dismantled.

label: Sawsan Sinijlawi
text:
Palestinians need a different kind of media coverage—one that does not reduce Palestinian suffering to a fixed identity or frame it as a permanent condition with no political horizon.
When discussion on certain news channels turns into performance rather than serious, developmental analysis, it stops being journalism. It becomes theater. Emotion replaces inquiry, repetition substitutes for understanding, and the search for solutions is replaced by the management of outrage.
When suffering is presented not as a reality that must be confronted and changed, but as a defining and permanent trait—an unavoidable fate with no political future—the risks are profound. And they are already unfolding. Palestinians risk being frozen inside a narrative that does not evolve: a closed story that allows no movement, no agency, and no space for internal debate.
In this kind of coverage, nuance and pluralism are often treated as betrayal. Internal criticism is framed as disloyalty. Any attempt to discuss responsibility, governance, or strategic decision-making is dismissed on moral grounds. The result is a discourse that generates international public sympathy while conditions on the ground continue to collapse, step by step.
Within this narrative, agency is outsourced to the outside world. The international community watches, reacts, and feels—but Palestinians are left trapped in an endless cycle of relived trauma. Media coverage relies heavily on continuous live reporting, yet rarely transitions into serious structural analysis. The recurring images of destruction and death produce emotional saturation rather than political clarity—impact without direction.
It is precisely here that the de facto leaderships in Gaza and Ramallah find a comfortable environment. A discourse of permanent victimhood and continuous suffering serves them politically. This is not a denial of Palestinian suffering—no honest person could deny it. The suffering is real, deep, and unjust.
But the way the story is told matters.
This style of coverage deliberately obscures a central fact: de facto authorities govern Gaza and the West Bank, and they make strategic decisions. Some of those decisions are taken with prior awareness that they may provoke catastrophic consequences, paid for primarily by civilians.
Journalism that cannot hold empathy and truth at the same time does not help Palestinians move forward. It preserves pain without opening a path out of it.
What Palestinians need—and what responsible media should offer—is coverage that restores agency, acknowledges complexity, and insists that suffering is not an eternal destiny, but a reality that must be analyzed, confronted, and ultimately overcome.
